questions.text: Which of the following muscles contributes to the extensor expansion of the ring finger?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The extensor expansion of the ring finger is formed by the extensor digitorum tendon (B) and receives contributions from intrinsic muscles like the lumbricals and interossei.

It is also known as the dorsal digital expansion, a fibrous structure that helps extend the finger.

  • A - Extensor carpi ulnaris
  • B - Extensor digitorum
  • C - Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis
  • D - Brachioradialis

Explanation for other options:

Extensor carpi ulnaris and extensor carpi radialis longus/brevis (Muscle A and C) are wrist extensors and do not insert into the extensor expansion.

Brachioradialis (Muscle D) is an elbow flexor and has no role in wrist or finger extension.

choices.text: Deep branch of the ulnar artery
Superficial palmar branch of the radial artery

questions.text: The main source of blood to the superficial palmar arterial arch is the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ulnar artery is the primary contributor to the superficial palmar arterial arch, which supplies the palm.

  • This arch is completed on the lateral (radial) side by the superficial palmar branch of the radial artery, forming an anastomotic loop across the palm.
  • The radial artery primarily forms the deep palmar arterial arch, which lies deeper in the palm. This arch is completed on the medial (ulnar) side by the deep branch of the ulnar artery, ensuring collateral circulation to the deep structures of the hand.

questions.text: A girl playing softball cuts the palm of her hand as she scoops up a piece of glass along with the ball. If the only nerve damaged is the recurrent branch of the median nerve, she would lose what movement of the thumb?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If the recurrent branch of the median nerve was injured, opposition of the thumb would be completely lost.

Course of the Median Nerve and Its Branches (on the hand)

  • The median nerve originates from both the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus (C5-T1).
  • It travels down the arm without giving any branches until it enters the forearm by passing between the two heads of the pronator teres.

In the forearm, it gives off the anterior interosseous nerve, which innervates:

  • Flexor pollicis longus
  • Pronator quadratus
  • The lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus

At the wrist, it passes through the carpal tunnel.

In the hand, it gives off the recurrent branch (also called the motor branch), which supplies:

  • Thenar muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis (superficial head), and opponens pollicis.
  • It also gives digital sensory branches to the lateral 3½ fingers and motor branches to the first and second lumbricals.

Explanation for other options:

Abduction (Option A): Still possible via abductor pollicis longus (radial nerve).

Adduction (Option B): The Adductor pollicis is supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Therefore, thumb adduction is unaffected by an injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Flexion of the distal phalanx (Option C) is performed by flexor pollicis longus (anterior interosseous branch of median nerve in the forearm), so not affected by injury to the recurrent branch.

questions.text: What sesamoid bone develops in the tendon of the flexor carpi ulnaris?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pisiform (A) is a sesamoid bone in the tendon of the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle.

  • It is in the proximal row of carpal bones.
  • It bears the forces generated by the tendon as the tendon rides across the triquetrum, especially during wrist extension.
  • Capitate is the largest carpal bone.
  • It is in the distal row of carpal bones, and it transmits forces generated in the hand to the lunate and then to the radius.
  • The lunate is a carpal bone in the proximal row that articulates with the capitate.
  • The scaphoid is the most lateral carpal bone in the proximal row.
  • It is found in the floor of the anatomical snuff box, and it is the most frequently fractured carpal bone.

questions.text: While watching her father split wood, a teenager was struck on the back of her carpals by a sharp-edged flying wedge. Her extensor digitorum tendons were exposed, though not severed, indicating that the surrounding synovial sheath had been opened. What other muscle has its tendon surrounded by the same synovial sheath?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The extensor indicis tendon is surrounded by the same synovial sheath as the extensor digitorum tendons.

  • Extensor indicis is a deep forearm extensor that specifically extends the index finger.
  • Its tendon joins the tendon of the extensor digitorum, going to the second digit.
  • Both tendons insert into the extensor expansion of the index finger.
  • Since they insert together, they are enclosed in a common synovial sheath within the dorsal compartment 4.

Explanation for other options:

Other tendons listed (Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicis brevis and longus) each have separate synovial sheaths and pass through different compartments. (Option B and C)

The supinator is a deep forearm muscle; it does not pass into the hand and has no tendon in the wrist synovial sheath. (Option A)

questions.text: What muscle tendon is enclosed within its synovial sheath in the carpal canal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flexor pollicis longus (C) is enclosed in its own synovial sheath called the radial bursa.

A - Interosseous membrane

B - Flexor digitorum profundus

C - Flexor pollicis longus

D - Flexor Retinaculum

  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) and flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) share a common synovial sheath called the ulnar bursa.
  • Both the radial bursa and ulnar bursa pass through the carpal tunnel.
  • The median nerve also runs through the carpal tunnel.
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris and palmaris longus do not pass through the carpal tunnel.

questions.text: Match the following, insertion points of forearm muscles;

choices.text: Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Dorsal branch of the ulnar nerve
Recurrent (motor) branch of the median nerve
Superficial branch of the radial nerve

questions.text: The fourth dorsal interosseous muscle is innervated by the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fourth dorsal interosseous muscle is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A deep puncture wound in the palmar surface of the little finger near the proximal IP joint might introduce infection directly into which synovial cavity:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

a superficial cut on the palmar side of the fifth digit can introduce an infection into the ulnar bursa (C).

A - Radial Bursa

B - Thenar Space

C - Ulnar Bursa

D - Mid-Palmar Space

  • The ulnar bursa is a common synovial sheath for the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus.
  • It extends from the wrist into the little finger and is continuous with the digital synovial sheath of the 5th digit (little finger).
  • A puncture in this location can directly communicate with the ulnar bursa, allowing the spread of infection into the palm and carpal tunnel.

Explanation for other options:

Radial Bursa (Option A): This is the synovial sheath of the flexor pollicis longus. It is limited to the thumb, not continuous with the little finger.

Thenar Space (Option B): This is a deep fascial compartment beneath the thenar muscles (thumb side) and not connected to the little finger.

Mid-Palmar Space (Option D): This is a deep fascial space in the central palm. While it can get secondarily infected from the little finger, the initial spread would most directly be into the ulnar bursa.

questions.text: After suffering a cut deep to the hypothenar eminence, the patient is unable to hold a sheet of paper between the second and third digits. The nerve most likely injured was the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To hold the piece of paper between the second and third digits, this patient needs to abduct the middle finger and adduct the second finger. So, the muscles involved are innervated by the deep branch of ulnar nerve (3).


1: The ulnar nerve

2: The transverse carpal ligament

3: Deep palmar branch of the hand

4: Anastomosis between the median nerve and ulnar nerve

5: Digital nerves

6: The median nerve.

questions.text: What movement of the thumb would be most affected by a lesion of the radial nerve in the cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Extension at both the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints would be most affected by a lesion of the radial nerve (posterior interosseous nerve) in the cubital fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the carpal tunnel?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum through Guyon's canal and is not a content of the carpal tunnel.

choices.text: The median nerve, the brachial artery, the biceps tendon, and the radial nerve
The radial nerve, the biceps tendon, the brachial artery, and the median nerve.
The median nerve, the brachial artery, the biceps tendon, and the anterior interossei nerve.
The radial nerve, the brachial artery, the brachioradialis, and the median nerve

questions.text: What is to medial-to-lateral content of the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cadaveric image shown is of the cubital fossa, and from medial to lateral, the contents of the cubital fossa include the median nerve, the brachial artery, the biceps tendon, and the radial nerve.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text: Assertion (A): The tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus in the hand are enclosed in a common synovial sheath. Reason (R): The ulnar bursa extends from the wrist to the distal phalanges of all four fingers
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Assertion is true: In the palm, flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) and flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)tendons are enclosed in a common synovial sheath called the ulnar bursa, especially where they pass under the flexor retinaculum.
  • The reason is false: The ulnar bursa does not extend to the distal phalanges of all four fingers; it typically continues into the digital synovial sheath of the little finger only, not all fingers.
